data.title: JSIL Based Implementation
data.body:
I saw the NaCl implementation to run in a browser but the flaw in that is that it only works in Chrome. JSIL is a program that converts CIL into JavaScript that will run in the browser. data.title: DXT Decompression on Android leaves black artifacts instead of transparent
data.body:
This is an issue I'm looking into where on Android some of our textures have black in the places where they should be transparent.

It only seems to affect our DXT Compressed .xnb's and not our normal Color .xnb's.

All of our texture content are marked for conversion to premultiplied alpha so the final .xnb should contain premultiplied alpha data.

Our project (Taptitude) runs on Windows Phone (with real XNA), Windows 8 (with MonoGame) and now on Android (with MonoGame) and only the Android version shows this problem.

All versions of the game use the same .xnb's which we compile from a single content project and then include in the various projects.

I'm guessing that on Windows with MonoGame we're able to use the hardware DXT texture format and it is correctly interpreting the data.

On Android it seems that there is a software conversion step and it is resulting in the black pixels instead of transparent pixels.

Has anyone else run into this?

I'll keep digging into it to see if there is some aspect of the decompression algorithm that would establish the premultiplied alpha nature of the data or if that is even the culprit.

data.title: Game reinitalization after orientation changes
data.body:
(This issue should replace issue  #1348 , because it's closer to the origin of the problem (that has nothing to do with a Nexus 7))

When running a default**\* "Hello from Monogame" project (**\* only extended the supported ScreenOrientation orienations: Activity: ScreenOrientation.Sensor and added DisplayOrientation.Portrait | DisplayOrientation.PortraitUpsideDown)

```
on a real device or on the emulator
and with a minimum Android target set to 4.0.3 or higher
```

and the orientation changes, then the app will be in a erroneous state:

First this happens:

GraphicsDeviceManager.ResetClientBounds --> AndroidGameWindow.DestroyFrameBuffer --> AndroidGameWindow.SurfaceDestroyed

Then the game will be reinitalized:

```
Game.Initialize will be called again
Game.LoadContent will be called again
```

=> the "Hello from Monogame" text will not be visible any more

You can reproduce this behaviour in the emulator. So it is not related to a specific device.

data.title: Fix rendertarget rendering (OpenGL)
data.body:
This is a fix to make rendertarget work as expected in OpenGL. This is a followup to #1399.  Here is the gist of it:
- There is no need to create one FBO per rendertarget; we can simply swap attachments when we call GraphicsDevice.SetRenderTargets; also this paves the way to multiple rendertargets support
- The default color buffer needs to be reset before frame swap (iOSGameView.Present) to ensure the one that might be created in the RenderTarget constructor doesn't interfere.

Tested on Infinite Flight (iOS), we use rendertargets quite extensively.

Also changed the behavior for the default  colorbuffer after being displayed (discarded instead of preserved).

data.title: Added ResumeManager so something can be drawn whilst textures are reloaded
data.body:
**How it works**
The textures are now reloaded on a different thread so execution can continue. The AndroidGameWindow._isResuming is set so the optional IResumeManager can be drawn. A default ResumeManager implementation has been provided so users can easily set it up with a custom texture rotating in the middle of the screen.

**Motivation**
Reloading of textures can take a LONG time. Whilst this occurs the user is presented with a black screen and the music playing. This leads to confusion about whether the game may have crashed. Also, when adding full screen ads to a game, these generally cause the GL context to be lost, so when the user dismisses the ad, they are hit with this lengthy texture reload each time.

**Usage**

```
// Create your own implementation of IResumeManager or simply use the
// default one. Place this code in your Game.Initialize() or somewhere similar
#if ANDROID
            AndroidGameWindow droidWindow = this.Window as AndroidGameWindow;
            droidWindow.SetResumer(new ResumeManager(this.Services,
                                                     spriteBatch,
                                                     @"UI\Resuming",
                                                     1.0f, // Default scale
                                                     0.02f // Rotate speed
                                                     ));
#endif
```

Original pull request in case someone wanted to check the comment history: https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/1093
